data.sampled:
The beetle has three types of wing color alleles (B, G, and T) with a dominance hierarchy B > G > T, where B has the highest dominance and T has the lowest dominance.

Parent Genotypes:

1. Blue: BB
2. Green: Gg
3. Turquoise: Tt

Offspring Genotypes:

1. B_ x B_: BB, Bb, Bb_
2. G_ x G_: Gg, Gg_, Gg_
3. T_ x T_: Tt, Tt_, Tt_

1. BB x BB -> 4/4 BB
2. Bb x Bb -> 4/4 Bb
3. Bb_ x Bb_ -> 4/4 Bb_
4. BB x Gg -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Gg
5. Bb x Gg -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Gg
6. Bb_ x Gg -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Gg
7. BB x Tt -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Tt
8. Bb x Tt -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Tt
9. Bb_ x Tt -> 3/4 BB, 1/4 Tt

Impossible:
N/A

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Turquoise -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Turquoise

data.expected: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
data.sampled:
The genotypes of the parents in the given example are BB and B_. The offspring are a result of a monohybrid cross, with the dominant allele being B, and the recessive alleles being g and t.

There is a 1:2:1 ratio for the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation. So, the genotypes of the offspring are 2BG:1GB:1GG.

The genotypes of the parents are BB and BB, where B stands for blue. The offspring are produced by sexual reproduction, so the genotypes of the offspring are determined by the parents' genes. Since the dominant allele B is heterozygous in the parents, there is a 50% chance that it will be passed down to the offspring. The other 50% of the offspring will receive the recessive allele t for turquoise.

data.sampled:
The genotypes of the parents and offspring in the given situation are as follows:

Parent Phenotype	Genotype	F1 Genotype
Green	G	GG (Green)
Turquoise	B	BB (Blue)
Blue	T	BT (Turquoise), B_ (Blue)

In the F1 generation, all individuals have the genotype BB (blue). The probability of the different phenotypes depends on the different possible genotypes that can arise from the cross between the different parents.

If the Green parent has the genotype G, there are two possible genotypes that can be produced from the cross with the Turquoise parent, namely GB and GT. Since the Green phenotype is dominant, the F1 offspring will all have the blue color.

Similarly, if the Turquoise parent has the genotype B, there are two possible genotypes that can be produced from the cross with the Green parent, namely BB and BT. Since the Turquoise phenotype is recessive, the F1 offspring will all have the blue color.

In summary, the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation would be 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 BT (Turquoise), 1/4 GB (Green, blue), 1/4 GG (Green, green).

data.sampled:
Randomly caught individuals:
B - blue
G - green
T - turquoise

Crossing between individuals:

BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_, all offspring will be blue
B_ (dominant T) x B_ -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 B_, 1/4 GG, 1/4 GB
Blue x G_ -> 2/4 BB, 2/4 B_, 4/4 Gg (dominant BB, dominant G)
G_ (dominant B) x G_ -> 3/4 B_, 1/4 G_ (dominant B), 4/4 Gg

In the first generation, the offspring will be polymorphic, expressing all three wing colors. The ratio of offspring with each wing color will be consistent with Mendel's Law of Segregation. For example:
4/4 B (blue): 2 (from B x B) + 1 (from B_ x B_) + 1 (from G x BB)
3/4 B (blue): 1 (from B x B_) + 1 (from G_ x G_)
1/4 B (blue) + 1/2 B_ (blue): 2 (from B_ x B_)
1/4 B (blue) + 1/2 G (green) + 1/4 GG (turquoise): 1 (from B_ x B_) + 1 (from G x BB) + 1 (from G_ x GG)
